The word, "thirsty" signifies the need for water for survival. The options provided are "California", "the henhouse", "the movie hall", "painting", and "Virginia". <n><n>California is an American state where it is very dry and drought is common. It is unlikely that the fox was there, which leaves the other four options.<n><n>The "henhouse" would be a good place to find water. The fox could either be hunting for water in the henhouse or it might be resting there to drink water that was already provided to the chicken.<n><n>"Movie hall" would not be a viable possibility because it is unlikely that the foxs could survive the drought by only watching movies. It would be unlikely to have water there.<n><n>"Painting" would also be ruled out because the fox would not have water there due to the drought. The question poses the option of the fox being "thirsty", indicating that it needs water for survival.<n><n>"Virginia" is also not a likely option because it is unlikely that a fox would have found water there due to the fact that it is a state in America, and in the context of the question, only dry and drought areas are considered. The word "thirsty" would not be used if the fox had already found water there.<n><n>Hence, the best option would be "the henhouse" as it provides a water source that is already there. If the fox was not there, it could explore the place and look for any hidden water source. Therefore, the best option is the phrase "in the henhouse".<n><n>#### Justification:<n>It is obvious that the character is referring to a henhouse as he/she is searching for water. Since the character is thirsty, the best options are either somewhere with water already there or somewhere that may have a water source. The best place to find water is already there and that is a henhouse.<n><n>### Input :A man asked which he would take, the first or the second?<n><n>Answer: The man is faced with alternatives, either taking the first or taking the second. The question could indicate an ambiguity. Both first and second are
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:The evacuation became mandatory, so what came on the TV? The answer is C "across the street" because it's a way to describe how the evacuees were sent.<n>2. "Across the street" can be used to describe a distance or direction. For instance: "We are from across the street".<n><n>### Output:The mayor sent the evacuationes across the street.<n><n>### Demo<n>Input: the mayor sent the evacuates across the street. <n><n>Rationales: The answer needs to be "evacuatees". Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Where are people likely to find food? Choices:  A: carpenter's shop B: video game C: garage D: total number E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n>D.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. "Carpenter's shop" seems to imply that it is one level only with each of the shop levels having two floors. Though other answers might be correct, it is impossible that there can be more than two floors in a single shop.<n>2. "Video Game" is possibly referring to a place to play video games where multiple games can be played on more than one level.  If that is not the case, this is still a correct guess but has two or more levels.<n>3. If a game is played on several different floors, "garage" is the word that would be used.<n>4. "Total number" is correct but not an answer that can be answered on an MCQ.  It would be an option to a follow-up question.<n>5. "Building" is the correct answer but is misleading since many constructions do not have "levels" in them but floors and stories.<n>6. That leaves us "D: total level", which is the best answer since a single construction on its own can only have a single "level", but that level can exist on more than one floor in the building.<n><n>### Input:"Gunpowder, along with his mother, were the two most powerful members of House Targaryen prior to the War of Conquest, and Gunpowder became one of the most powerful men in Westeros after the fall of Mad King Aerys II." His mother" is grammatically wrong, and so is not an answer. <n>5. He wasn't referring to His mother's Gun, which makes choice 4 the wrong choice.<n><n>### So,

The speaker asked.<n><n>### Response:"Sure."  My stomach growled.<n>Choices:  A: My mother's B: my mother's C: My mom's<n><n>### My sister's<n>Rationales:<n>1. The correct answer is "A: My mother's".  The pronoun "her" that follows the word "these" refers to "these delicious cookies" since "cookies" is an object, therefore the pronoun "her" which is an object pronoun should not be capitalized.<n>2. "My mother's" correctly capitalizes the pronoun "her".<n>3. "My mother' s" and "My mother's" do not capitalize the pronoun "her", which is an error.<n>4. Choice C, "My mom's", contains an extra space where there shouldn't be any: it is not a possessive pronoun "My mom's" but rather a contraction of "My mother's".<n>5. "My sister's" is clearly a possessive pronoun ("my sister's"), not the contraction for "My mother's", as in Choice C, so it is a wrong answer.<n>6. Choice B, "my mother's", appears to have a hyphen in the middle; however, this is incorrect as no word following "my mother's" is capitalized "my mother's".<n>7. Choice D, "her," is not a correct answer because the pronoun should be referred to as "her".  The possessive for "she" is "hers."<n><n>### Input:(Must say in class)What do you eat for dinner? "Buying" and "buy" are synonymous, "I got...then because it was usually..." suggests there was a sale already.<n>3. Choices:  a: bored b: happy c: sad d: scared, surprised, or happy e: all of the above<n><n>### Response:"I am feeling bored."  It's the most direct and concise explanation of that feeling.  The other sentence options might be true for a little while, but it is ultimately the feeling of boredom that we are going to talk about with "which of the options describes my feeling". Choice b could be true if you were bored for a short period.  Choice c could also be true if you were sad for a brief period, but boredom lasts more than a few minutes.  Choices d and e could be true at any point in time, so they don't capture specific information about the moment of feeling bored.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input : I have a bad temper. <n>#### What is missing?<n>Choices: a bad mood <n><n>### Response  A: a bad mood<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Sarah wanted to by a new rug.  Ink spilled onto her old one.  Really, she didn't know what that thing had an inkwell in the first place.  What piece of furniture might have been on her run? Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* "A: The front of the door."<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>* The question mentions that Sarah wanted to buy a new rug and the old rug had an ink spill that she didn't know how to clean.<n><n>* Then the passage mentions how Sarah didn't know what the thing had an ink well in the first place.<n><n>* Sarah didn't know how clean the ink spill, so it must have been on a piece of furniture.<n><n>* Sarah says "What piece of furniture was on my run?" which suggests that it was out in the open.<n><n>* Sarah does not mention a bedroom, living room, desk or table in the passage.<n><n>* Thus, the best fit is "A: The front door."<n><n>## Resources<n><n>* [1] [Exercise 21](https://github.com/saharajha/Practice-AI-Interview/blob/master/resources/exercises/exercise21.jpg)<n>

Choices:  A: notoriety B: emotional distress C: riot D: bad dreams E: annoyance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Demand: Telling many people about an embarassing situation. Response: Bad dreams.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The question asks about what would result from telling many people about an embaissing situation. Among the given options, "notoriety", "riot", "emotional distress" and "annoyance" are not the ones that would most likely result from the act of telling many people about an awkward situation. <n><n>The correct answer must be one of the options that indicates something negative or unpleasant, the word that best fits the bill is "Bad dreams." <n><n>"Bad dreams" would be something that many people who are being told about an embarassing moment or situation would experience, since they might be thinking of the humiliating thing that had been shared with them, thus making this the most likely answer. <n><n>Among the given options, "riot", "notoriety" and "emotional distrss", these are too general and broad to be the most likely response to sharing unpleasant information about a situation. <n><n>"Riot" only indicates physical violence as a result of such information being shared, but that is not the only reason why there might be a negative response or consequence when telling people about an embarrasing. <n><n>"Notoriety" also cannot be a likely response, since that would not result simply in knowing about an embarassing incident, it would also involve other negative events, as in fame or infamy. <n><n>As for "emotional distres", that would imply that a person would experience something negative in relation to the embarassing info being given, but only to a lesser extent than "Bad dreams". <n><n>Having established that "Bad dreams" is the answer to the given question, it is the most likely response, the correct choice.<n><n>### Output: <n>[![](https://img.shields.io/github/workflow/status/wilson-christian-perez/challenge-1/Building%20Chatbot)](https://wilson-chistian-perez.github.io/Challenge-1/)

Choices:  A: bike B: downtown C: building D: tool storage E: car<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: James has a garage. It is built for tool storage, which is the function of a storage garage.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1.The question implies that James used to store whatever he liked or preferred to store. (ex: bikes, cars)<n><n>2.A storage garage would not be a solution for a person who doesn't own property in the region to begin with. <n><n>3.A bike.  Building. And car are all items that are owned by James but a Storage-Garage is not.<n><n>4. The item garage is for, or it's function is tool storage. James owned a car and building and a bike but a garage is an item, not a function.<n><n>5. Thus, the correct answer should be: D: tool storage.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:What emotion do people expressing themselves show when they trip in front of a crowd and break their leg? Choices:  A: communication B: suffering C: pain D: laughter E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: laughter<n><n>### Rationales: <n>1. A and C are incorrect because we cannot know what the public's response would be. People's reactions may vary based on their personalities, experience and so on.<n>2. B is incorrect because the emotion is what a person expresses, and it is impossible to know everything a person feels. We might only see one part of the reaction, such as suffering or pain.<n>3. C is incorrect because it is pain, not suffering, that the emotion would show due to a physical injury. <n>4. E is incorrect because we never really know the response of people in a crowd.  Also, we can never be certain that they will not laugh at the person's misery since they may feel compassion, disgust, and so on.<n><n>5. Therefore the correct answer is D: laughter, which captures the possible emotion of people expressing themselves.<n>6. The person's physical injury might generate some laughter. Even if it is not the desired result, we cannot be certain that people would not express themselves this way. <n>7. Thus, the choice that is correct is D: laughter.<n><n>### Input : <n>> The man was so ashamed of himself that he left the restaurant and did not eat that night at all. Choices:  A: apartment B: classroom C: buildings D: car E: audience<n><n>### Response:		<n>There was only one word given in the passage such that "no more than around 120 people" could contain, meaning that it must then be "more than 100 people" in the same sentence, implying that its number is 110.<n><n>For the option A, "the apartment" could only contain around 120, which is more, but it is not 110. <n><n>For the option B, "a classroom" could contain a hundred in the same room and a couple of extra students in another room, but it is not more than 110 in total.  <n><n>For the option, "a building" could contain a hundred people or more in every floor, but a building could be divided into multiple buildings, so it is not more than a couple buildings.  <n><n>For option c, "buildings" could contain a couple buildings each with over a hundred in one building but less than 120 people, but it is not a hundred in each building.<n><n>For option D, "the audience" is a possible option because it could mean the number of people attending an event and be more than a hundred people.  <n><n>For Option E"the audience" is not an option because there is no indication in the passage that "the audience" contains more than a hundred people, and it might not contain more than 120.  The passage's word indicates otherwise.<n><n>The answer to the question is A: apartment.  <n><n>Answer: A: apartment<n>### Input: I wish that I had been more attentive to my homework assignments, I wouldn't be in this situation. Choices:  A. worse B. more difficult<n>Rationales: The answer to the above question is E. The word "in this situation", implies that we are in a situation that is worse than what we wished for. E is the only option that indicates a worse situation.<n><n>A. worse is not an option because it doesn't necessarily relate to the homework assignments.<n>B. is not an option because "more difficult" doesn't indicate that we are in a worse situation, but rather it implies that it is a difficult situation.<n><n>The answer is E. (Worse)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by only a few people recently? Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A. The question implies that the location of air containing recently breathed air by a few people would be a train station.<n>B. The house would contain dust that is a result of many people living in the same space, but it is unlikely that it will contain air with just a few recent breathers.<n>C. A cupboard may contain air that has been breathe by only a few people (for example, when a couple leaves their home and leaves the cupboard in their kitchen open during their absence). However, the passage does not specify if it needs to be air breathed by people who recently entered the house, implying that the presence of a few recent breather in the air in the house is sufficient to meet the requirement.<n>D. The cricket stadium doesn't seem to be suitable to meet the requirement. <n>E. The surface of the earth would contain air containing the breathe of every person on the earth (if it's not covered by any large body of water) but it's unlikely that the air would only contain the breathe of a few recent humans.

The most water an appliance can use is the blender because it can use a very large volume of liquid and the only liquid it might use is water.<n>4. Disneyland cannot use water or soap.<n>5. Thus the only appliances that actually use water and soap are the blender and the washing machine.<n>6. The washing machine uses more water than the blender, and has soap, so the washing machine is a better choice. <n>7. For the same reasons, Space shuttle cannot use water or soap either.<n><n>Answer: A: Washing machine

Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: F: happiness<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1. This is a multiple choice question that requires the correct answer to be "happiness".  Since the whole family was playing cards with joy, the correct answer must fit this condition.  Among the options provided, "sadness", "amusement", "losing money", and "anger" cannot be correct choices because they do not represent situations where "joy" and "happiness" are present.<n>2. The appropriate answer must be "happiness", which is a state of joy.  Other non-happiness states that can be inferenced from the given situation are "sadness", a lack of joy, and "losing money", which is not present in the situation as the family has plenty to be happy about, not counting any losses during the game.<n>3. It is impossible that the family is "amused" in the situation described in the question because being "amused" means being entertained by something in a way that connotes humor, which is absent in the given scenario.<n>4. Moreover, the presence of "anger" cannot be inferenced here due to the family playing cards, though it can be inferred in different situations where some members are playing against one another rather than together as a group.<n><n>### Input:"Sure now you look to be all swollen with grief." Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is [D: placemat]. <n><n>### Rationales: Among the given options, [D: placmat] is the correct choice because a spoon would be placed on a [placemat] on either side of a plate.  <n>The other options are incorrect (A: bowl of soup,B:serving dish, and others) because they are not close enough to [D:plachmat] or [D:plat] to indicate that [D:plachmt] is the answer.<n><n>### Input - Demonstration: <n>The question asks, "What is the maximum number of guests allowed at a wedding reception?" (Maximum number of guests allotment [Maximum guests limit/maximum limit])<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>* There are 5 choices given, answer the question by choosing the best fit.<n>* There are no other options (options B- E).<n><n>Rationales: To understand the questions, we use the first three steps in the [5 Ws and H].<n>* What: "What is the maximum allotment of guests?"<n><n>* Who: "Who is the question regarding?" "This question is about the reception of a wedding."<n><n>* When: "When is the question asking?" "It's asking during the wedding reception."<n><n>* Where: "Where is the question asking?" The question asks about the reception of a "wedding," which would take place in a "venue."<n><n>* Why: "Why are these things being asked?" "The why is unclear, as this is not usually necessary for a multiple choice question."<n><n>* How: This is more a question of "how much," as the "many" indicates there might be multiple guests.<n><n>### Answer - Demonstration<n><n>The correct choice that answers the question is [C: 250]. <n><n>This choice is the best fit because the question specifically asks about the maximum allotment and the choices for receptions for a wedding (like the choices [A: 300-400], [B: 50-100] and [D: unlimited])<n><n>The best fit also fits within the limits of the venue and fits with the "many" used in the context.<n><n>However, the best

Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer is E. Chess game.<n><n>## How it works<n><n>The idea behind the parser is that it should follow a very simple paradigm: "take command as input, parse it, execute it, collect results and print".<n><n>Each type of command is represented by a class that implements the `CommandExecutor` interface. All the classes that implement CommandExecutor extends the `Command` class that is responsible to handle all the business logic in command implementations:<n><n>    class Question implements CommandExecutor {<n><n>        /**<n>         *  Set of questions<n>         */<n>        private final Set<String> questions = new HashSet<>();<n><n>        @Override<n>        public String execute() {<n>            String question = this.questions.remove(input);<n>            //if (question!= null) {<n>                System.out.println(question);<n>            } else {<n>                System.err.println("Unknown command!");<n>            }<n>            return null;<n>        }<n><n>        protected void addQuestion(String question) {<n>            this.questions.add(question);<n>        }<n>    });<n><n>Each type of class is identified by an enum that contains the CommandExecutor class:<n><n>    enum Command {<n>        QUESTION(Question.class) {<n>            public static String QUESTION = "question";<n>        },<n>        SINGLE_SELECT(SingleSelect.getCommandExecutor().getClass()) {<n>            public static final String SINGLE_SELECT = "select";<n>        },<n><n>        /**<n><n>         *  - List of Choices<n>         *    - Choice must be associated with a Question otherwise it<n>         *      will be ignored<n>         * - Number of Choices per Question<n>         * - Default option per question<n>         * - Answers from the user must be equal to the choices<n>         */<n>        CHOICE_SELECT(ChoiceSelect.class) {<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>Now, the CommandExecutor classes can be registered with the CommandExecutorList class:<n><n>    CommandExecutorList.registerWithCommandExecutor(Command.QUESTION, QUESTION_COMMAND_EXECUTOR_LIST);<n>    CommandExecutorList<n><n>These lists are implemented by the same logic.<n><n>The above code makes it possible to have a generic interface that can be easily extended for more complex commands.<n><n>The parser code is

Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: work out<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question is about getting in shape, and the choices provided are actions that can help people get in shape.<n>2. Among the choices, "swim", "jog", "exercise", "work out" and "rock climb", "work out" is the best fit to indicate a complete and comprehensive activity that will help one get in shape.<n>3. "Swim" might suggest that one can go swimming to help one get in shape, but this requires a body of water, which may require a long commute or travel to a different location, depending on the body of water one chooses to swim in.<n>4. "Jog" may indicate running, but it does not capture the comprehensive nature of a workout and does not necessarily mean that one will get in shape as a result of jogging.<n>5. "Exercise" may indicate various workouts, but it does not specifically require the use of a gym and may not include all the necessary elements of a comprehensive workout routine.<n>6. "Rock climb" may indicate an activity that requires significant strength and endurance.<n>7. But since it does not necessarily involve a gym, it might not be appropriate to get in shape in this way.<n>8. In general, "work out", implying a comprehensive and intensive exercise routine is the best fit to help one get in healthy and shape.<n>9. The rationale is to provide a complete and comprehensive answer to the question.<n>Answer: D work out.<n>

Choices: A: an unidentified person  B: the family dog C: raccoons  D: a squirrel  E: the wind<n><n>### Response2:<n><n>C: Raccoons<n><n>### Exlanation2:<n>C:  It mentioned that their neighbors saw him on the trail several times, which it's a very common path to walk around the area. <n><n>Additionally, The next day there was a noise in his room, and he was startled, but when he went looking for the noise, it had been gone. Which strongly suggests that it was the noise of a raccoon.<n><n>### Input3:The police are saying that a man was shot in the head in his apartment, but how was he sitting there with a what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? You cannot store a tent in the woods, the campground, or your backpack.<n><n>### Input :Several new laws are expected to pass in the next legislative session.  Choose the best synonym for 2. This means that it needs to be secure from breeze, bloc, or consensus, not bloc or breeze.<n><n><n>--<n>### Input 6 :  In lawmaking committees, the person A  : who votes and represents a country  Choices:  : representative  : majority   : consensus

Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Lindy was a senior.  He lived with his children because he didn't want to go where? He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Choices:  A - B - C - D - E - F<n>3. F: "a lot of free goodies"<n><n>### Submission:<n>```jsx<n>import React from'react'.<n><n>export default () => (<n>    <div><n>        <h1>Write the response that appropriately complements or rebuts  the statement above. </h1><n>        <div><n>            <input value='A: to be heard' type='text' id='commentInput' <n>            defaultValue='A: to be listened to' onKeyDown<n>            onKeyUp<n>            onPaste={e => e.preventDefault()} <n>            onInput={e => event.preventDefault()}<n>            onChange={e => console.log(this[e.target.id + 'value'])<n>            }/><n>        </div><n>    </div><n>);<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Rationales: There is a list problem; there are 5 answers and only three are used.<n><n>The list of words is in a sentence. There is a list that goes with a definition in a row, and then there is no context for the list. We should check if the sentence is a fragment or if it's an incomplete thought because there is a word that makes sense to put there, which is "how". There isn't an explanation for why we didn't get that word. Another list problem is that there are two choices that begin with the same word, which is "make", the 2nd word from the last in the list. That should be crossed out. For the remaining three choices, "build". "entice" is not the correct answer. "build" makes complete sense in the sentence and the only missing word is "a".<n><n>Answer: <n>I think that the right answer is: build<n><n>### Input :  The city of Tuscaloosa, Alabama will hold its annual Mushroom Festival this weekend. A bookstore would not be a logical place to get a bag after it has been filled with clothes as books are typically their primary product.<n>6. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:What chore might a child have to do after breakfast, before getting on the bus? At once we began driving south, following it through city after industrial city. At dusk, we turned onto a muddy road, our wheels slipping and sliding. From the darkness I could see a red light looming ahead as we crept into the city’s downtown. After a while, we reached what appeared to be an old, abandoned warehouse. The walls had crumbling paint and large chunks of wood were missing from them. “Is this where we stay? Will you help me dig in?” He said to me, and I nodded. I grabbed the shovel. Then we got to work. We started to dig, and we dug fast because we were cold and it was slipping away from us. Soon the floor of the building began to be wet, and then mud. After a while, it became just mud. Then we hit wood. It was old, rotting wood. So we had to dig it out. It took us so long to dig it out because the floor under the wood was wet and spongy. The wood smelled awful. And then we hit a metal thing. It was a big, old can, filled with the same blood as we had dug out of the ground. I couldn’t see into it. At the top of the can was a lid of some sort, but it had a dent in it. We dug it out with our shovel. “Do you think it’s what we are supposed to find in there?” I asked Biff “I think that’s it.” Biff said, and he grabbed the metal tin and threw it over his shoulder.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>#### Key Points<n><n>1) In the first paragraph,Biff and I took to highway<n><n>2) Biff said to me, “Is this where we are going to stay? Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Bob needs a level to hang a shelf but cant find one in his home. Where would he go to get one? How the issue is phrased, if in doubt, ask your teacher for clarification.<n><n>### The perspective:<n>2. When it is a choice between two options, state the perspective and one of them, not both.<n><n>### Context:<n>3. This is optional, use it if you wish to provide context.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? User still prefers to have C,"Getting Drunk", but since user has already eliminated that choice, users might want to know that what is the meaning of,"Getting Drunk". The meaning of,"Geting Drunk" is not like "beeing drunk", it is what happens before you are completely drunk. After all, what hospital bed doesn't have at least several inches of legroom?<n>(Assignment Expectation): Demonstrate your ability to summarize the data and draw appropriate inferences based on it. <n><n>### Solution<n>```<n>class Solution:<n>    def validSquareRoot(self, square: int) -> bool:<n>        if square == 0:<n>            return False<n>        n = floor(sqrt(square))<n>        return (n**2 == square)<n>```<n><n>```<n>Input: The square root of 2 is an irrational number. Choices:  A B C D E<n>```<n><n>```java<n>class Solution:<n>    <n>    def mySqrt(self, x: int) -> int:<n>        while (x < 2):<n>            x = x * 3<n>        x = x // 2<n>        while (x > 2):<n>            ans = x // 2;<n>            x = x - ans**2;<n>            if (x > 2)x = x - ans<n>        return ans<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Use the code and the commentary below to evaluate the provided function `solution.mysqrt(x)` that solves the non-linear equation `mySqrt(x)` = x. <n><n>The program takes in the value(s) of x (as an integer) for testing and evaluates whether the value is within the range of the correct answer.<n><n>Print a one-line message that reports whether ‘x’ is within the correct range.<n><n>`x < 2` means that the square root is less than 2.<n><n>`x > 2` means that it is less than or equal to zero.<n><n>In addition to the code you have not yet seen, the file solution contains function definitions for <n><n>`sqrt(n)` and two helper functions: <n><n>`ceil(n)` and `floor(n)`.<n><n>**Note:** These functions will be made available to you when you run the code. <n><n>## Instructions:<n>The following statement is valid if and only if either $a$ or $b$ is undefined. <n>If both are defined, it evaluates to `true`.

He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Dry and cracked heels are found on? Choices: Choices: A: fail B: find C: learn D: understand E: realize<n><n>## Rationales: 1.) The statement that "rudimentary skills are sufficient for a solo" implies that having some knowledge of how to play a song is sufficient for a solo.<n><n>2.) The statement about "one of the group workshopps" could be interpreted as an example of where a beginner might start by learning the basics with others who are also trying to learn how to play.<n><n>3.) The statement that "You may learn something in your choir, even at a group workshop" indicates that a beginner could learn something in a choir and from participating in group workshops, even if they were low level events.<n><n>4.) "You might just" indicates that there is a possibility that someone might learn something by participating in a soloist workshop, an experienced teacher, a choir, or a group workshop.  The correct answer, therefore, is Choice D: "realize".<n><n>Answer: D: realize<n><n>### Input : He's a brilliant doctor. In addition, the fact that John said that it "seemed impossible" before they succeeded, implies his approval and praise.<n>4. Finally, it is mentioned later that the result was a considerable success, indicating satisfaction with the result and praise.<n>5. Thus, the answer to the demand is "YES" in agreement with the response of the characters.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? The fact that I live there is purely coincidental.<n><n>### Input<n>1. What are some of the advantages of the Internet? Choices: A: it is free, B: it has a good variety of media, C: it is reliable, D: it is very private, E: it is very fast, F: it is very reliable, G: it is very private.<n><n>### Response<n><n>1. One advantage to using the Internet is that it is reliable. For example, we don't have to worry about physical paper and ink.<n>2. However, another disadvantage is that it is private. For example, people have posted images of themselves on social media and regret it, even though it is legal to do so. <n><n>### Exaplination<n><n>### Input::<n><n>1. One disadvantage to using the internet is that it is very private. For example, we are more susceptible to online harassment and sexual assault by people who hide behind faceless forums. <n><n>2. Another advantage to using the internet is is that its very fast. For example, you can find a video you like by typing it into a search engine. <n><n>3. However, one disadvanatage to the internet is that it can't be easily verified. <n><n>4. Another disadvantage to internet is that people use it to distort facts.<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions<n>Analyze this paragraph. You can answer any or all three short answer questions as well as one long answer questions.<n><n>### Analysis: Paragraph1:<n><n>### First sentence: It was written in June of 1927 and was published in
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:He found the blowfish off the coast of the Carolina's, it was where? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:  <n>```python<n>import sys<n>sys.stdout = open(sys.argv[1], "w")<n>s=input()<n><n><n>if s.find("surface")!= -1:<n>  print("A: surface of the moon.")<n>else:<n>  print("D: ground. You're too dark.")<n>```<n><n>This question deals with the correctness of the syntax of the code provided.It should be a well formed code using python syntax.<n><n>### Input:`a.f(g(h(i(g(j(j))))))`<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Answer: Input: `a.f(g.h(i.j(j)))`<n>```python<n>def f( x ):<n>    return x * x<n><n>def g( x ):<n>   return x * x * x<n><n><n>def h( x ):<n>     return x * x * 2<n><n><n>def i( x ):<n>       return x * x *2<n><n><n>def j( x ):<n>        return 2 * x<n><n><n>f(g(h(.))) + i(j(.))<n>```<n><n>Another question deals with correctness of syntax of code in python<n><n>### Input:"if there is a square in the bottom row, then the row immediately above it is empty."<n><n>### Demosration:<n><n>```input: if there is a square in row 1, then there is no square in row 2.<n><n>a.<n>      _<n>      \<n>       \<n>        \<n>         \ <n>          \<n>           \<n>            _<n><n>b.<n>      / <n>      \<n>       / \<n>     /    \_<n>      /     \<n>       \<n>       \<n>     \<n>      \<n>       _ <n>```<n><n>Input:" if there is a square is the bottom row, then it must be the only one." If there is another square in that same line, it will be the only one. Otherwise, it will not be the only one. <n>

Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:She a deep love for all her friends, every Friday she had an open invitation for them as she loved to host and what? Choices:  A: wait for B: eat out C: entertain D: please parents E: paint<n><n>### Response:		Please parents<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Based from how the question was asked, it was intended to capture how she would entertain her friends. "Wait for" is out of place as a response. It could have been used if the sentence reads, "She had a deep love for everyone and would wait for her friends.". "Wait for" would most likely follow "every".<n>Since she entertained her friends by hosting, "entertain" is a good alternate to "please parents". <n>It could also be taken as "entertain parents" since the text states "every Friday." That would be the correct reasoning then. "Paint" is not applicable, as the whole sentence does not refer to a painting. <n>Lastly, "paint" does not fit with a deep love for friends.<n><n>### Input "She was wearing a pink one-shoulder top and a white skirt, and as she walked what? He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:The circus monkey waived a white surrender flag, the conductor joked the monkey must work in the what? The prefix, "com," means with, and "passion," means to suffer.<n>3. So, the word "compassionate" means to feel deep sympathy and sorrow for someone else who is suffering.<n>4. Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		<n>**1.**The word "meet" in the question does not have a particular preposition and therefore the appropriate verb to use is "meet".<n><n>**2.**A preposition is not always needed when a verb ending with "ing" is used.<n><n>**3.**You can say, "People tend to meet people when socializing." This indicates the meaning that people who socialize are people who meet people. <n><n>**4.**In "meet people," people precedes the noun people so there is no necessity to use the preposition "with".<n><n>**5.**"Mingle" indicates mixing up or mixing, but it doesn' help us understand the meaning of "meet people." <n><n>**6.**"Meet people" and "mingle" are different functions.<n><n>**7.**"Meet" is a verb followed by "people" and "mingle is a noun followed by "people," thus "meet people" is correct while "mingle people" is incorrect.<n><n>**8.**"Meet new people" is not the meaning of the sentence. <n><n>**9.**"Mingling people" is also incorrect because people precedes mingle.<n><n>**10.**"New" indicates something different while "people" doesn't, thus, "people" is not a correct choice.<n><n>**11.**"Mingled" with people doesn't make any sense and "made friends" is a non-sequence. <n><n>**12.**"Meet friends" is also incorrect because of the incorrect pronunciation of "friends" and "tails," "new people" doesn't make any semantic sense while "friends" is a separate noun to "people."<n><n>**13.**"Mingler people" doesn't mean a lot either because "mingle" doesn't refer to people but indicates mixing up. <n><n>**End.**Correct Answer:**D: Small Talk<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the sentence below.<n>### Demonstraion:Input: ________ is an undergraduate course that you may choose to complete to satisfy a requirement for your ________. Choices:  A: curiosity B: excitement C: boredom D: wonder E: fear<n><n>### Response:		B: excitement<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The question is asking what a person feels when they are seeing new things, and the provided choices are all possible feelings when experiencing something new. <n>2. If a person is seeing new places, new people, new things, etc., they are likely to feel new experiences, which makes "excitement" the appropriate answer. <n>3. There is no other choice that suggests a feeling of excitement, making "excitement" a rational choice among the available options.<n>4. Moreover, if someone is feeling bored or fearful, they are unlikely to be seeing new things. <n>5. Similarly, if they are seeing new things but feeling bored or fear, it likely doesn't fit the question because they say they are seeing new things.<n>6. Thus, the only remaining choice is excitement, which is the correct answer. <n><n>### Answer:D: excitement<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:What part of the body are lips on? Choices:  A: washing machine B: laundromat C: clothing store D: closet E: shopping mall<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is D: Closet.<n> <n>### Instruction - Why are there no question marks after the question?<n><n>This is the style guideline for questions on test2go.  <n>There are no question marks because answer choices are provided, thus avoiding the inconvenience of providing them in the question itself.<n><n>### Input - Write your thought process when you are confronted with the question with no answer choices.<n><n>As with all multiple choice questions, I would first read the instructions carefully and then look for the answer that is provided:<n> <n>Demonstration - What is the correct answer for the following multiple choice question?<n><n>Input: John only did what was required.  He was negligent.  He wanted to do a good job, so he would have done more if he... Choices A: were more qualified; B: were not required; C: were a friend of John; D: had the time; E: were not paid<n><n>### Input<n>I would read the question and answer choices to see if I can figure the meaning out on my own, or need to ask for help.  There is no "correct" way to do this because every student's reading ability is likely different.<n><n>### How would you write it for a student who is more advanced? (advanced students might be a bit stumped on a low-level question, but could easily help a student struggling with the same question)<n><n>The advanced test-taker should explain why they choose the answer they do.  For example:<n><n>Closet: The question says that John was more qualified than the other possible answer choices, so he would have completed everything required of him; hence, "had the time."<n><n>So the advanced student's response would include the "rationale" that John did everything required by law, and he was more qualified to do so than any of the other answer choices for which the reason they couldn't was not that they were not paid or not required.<n><n>### Avoiding "I don't know."<n><n>When you're asked a question you do not know the answer to, you either know and forgot (I know the answer, I just can't form it into an acceptable response) or you don't know it (I don't know how to find the answer or what that answer is).<n><n>

Choices:  A: fresh water B: gulf of mexico C: open ocean D: television program E: coral reef<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A.  Fresh water.  Biologists found sharks in freshwater from time to time before the recent discovery [of a large population of sharks](https://www.businessinsider.in/Inside-the-lake-where-thousands-of-sharks-are-living-in-the-safest-place-in-the-world/articleshow/65070532.cms) in the Great Lakes, which is a large freshwater system [connects to the Atlantic Ocean](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/habitats/great-lakes/). <n><n>### Dem:<n>- Biologists found shark in freshwater from time-to-time before the recent discovery of a large population of shark in the Great Lakes.<n>     - The word "from" in the beginning of the sentence indicates that biologists had discovered sharks in freshwater previously.<n>     - The sentence further supports this with the information "in the Great Lakes". This supports the previous statement that biologists discovered sharks in fresh water previously.<n>     - Biologists found the majority of sharks in these Great Lakes between the years 1934 and 1937.<n>```<n>It is also said that between 1934-1937, a large number and variety of sharks could be found in these Great Lakes.<n>```<n>     - Biologist also started finding smaller numbers and types of sharks from 1940 onwards, and eventually they became extinct in 1946.<n>     - So, the sentence can be read as "Biologists previously found them in fresh water, but it was rare, and they were not found after 1937."<n>     - Thus, A is correct.<n><n>B.  Gulf of Mexico.<n><n>C.  Open ocean.<n><n>D.  Television program.<n><n>E.  Coral Reef.<n><n>### Answer:<n>D: Open Ocean.<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>- TV program seems out of place. It does not mean a television show or a program that is broadcast over the radio and doesn't fit with the context.<n><n>- Open ocean is suitable among the remaining choices as the Great Lakes only

Options: A: dairy farm, B: Texas, C: Building, D: Michigan, and E: Florida. <n><n>### Response 2:<n>  C) Building<n><n>### Rationales: 1.) The options provided include a dairy farm, texas, building, Michigan, and Florida.  Dairy farm and texas are not likely to be considered a "steakhouse" since it is known as a "beefhouse."<n>2.) The answer is the best choice of the provided options, since building implies a location (i.e., a building), which is the opposite of a steakhouse being a place of food.  Therefore it does not make sense for James to travel to a steakhouse after already being in a steakhouses in order to eat.<n>4.) In addition to the rational above, "building" is the only option that is not geared towards Texas, Michigan, or Florida.  It is the only option that would logically fit the context, since the options given indicate that the steakhouse is outside of Texas, Michigan, or florida. 5.) It should be noted that while James is technically in a building, he is unlikely to be in a building that acts as a steakhouse since food services are not allowed in an office building and/or public building.

Therefore, the answer to this question is E.<n><n>### Input:"Let's make it a double" and "Make mine an old-fashioned"? Choices:  A:"I'll get it myself" B: "Two of those, please" C: "Give me another" D: "Two of these, please." E: "No, keep the change"<n><n>### Response:"D"<n><n>### Rationales: In order to answer this question, you must understand the context of the lines. The lines occur in a dialogue between two individuals at a bar, and the two sentences you are given are in response to a drink being ordered.  The sentence "I'll get it" (response A) can be inferred to mean "I'll get the drink myself," suggesting that the person ordering the drink may choose to self-serve instead of waiting for the waiter or bartender.  The sentence "Make mine an old fashioned" (response B) would seem to request a different type of drink  The sentence "Two of those, thanks" (response C) would indicate a request for two drinks.  The sentence "Give me another one" (response D) is also a request for another drink.   The sentence "No, keep the changed" (response E) is a refusal to pay for the drink, suggesting that the drink was on the patron's tab.  Thus, the best response to the question, "what would be the appropriate response to each of these sentences" is response 'D':  make mine an old-fashioed.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:The friends loved competing against one another, it was a good way to work their what? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B: pay merchandise with money.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1. Given the question's context of a store, it makes logical sense for customers to pay merchandise (with money) rather than hunt the store for what they need to buy.<n>2. This is explicitly stated in the choices D (demand satisfaction) and E (spend money).<n>3. The options don't necessarily describe what customers do in a store (or if they do, they do not specify the store's context, which is the reason for being in the store, i.e. purchase merchandise).<n>4. "Give" in the options C (mail orders) and E (demand satisfaction) suggests that the options do not necessarily result from a customer's activity in a store but are instead outside the store (perhaps in mail or some kind of service request for satisfaction).<n>5. The only choice that really does describe what customers do in the context of a store is B (pay merchants with money).<n>6. Of the choices that seem to indicate what customers do in a commercial setting such as a store, B (pay merchandise with the money), is the only one that explicitly indicates a payment which is the reason for the customers being in the store. <n>7. Thus, answer B (merchandise) best fits the question as it describes what customers do when they are in a store.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input John saw the woman but he did not hear her approach. I was angry. Nothing was good.<n><n>### Response1:<n>Answer1: a. I was happy, because I could help my family.<n><n>### I wanted to play with my nieces and nephews.<n><n>### Answer2:<n>Answer: b. I want the dog to die.<n><n>### Rationale1<n><n>We can see from the example here that "I like to play with the children" can be considered grammatical, while "I like to play the children" is<n>grammatically incorrect. The reason for this is that the correct usage of "play" requires an inanimate object (the dog). In the case of <n>"children" being an inanimate object, the sentence should have followed the sentence structure described at the top of the page: "I like to play<n>with THE child."<n><n>This principle also applies to "play" with the verb "help."<n><n>The following sentence is an example of a grammatical error in the phrase "play" with: "I like to help the dog." Here, we can see that it should be "I <n>like to HELP the dog," which follows the form of the phrase "I like to help THE kid."<n><n>For these two reasons, we can conclude that "play" with is incorrect, while "help" with is correct.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: John only gave a perfunctory examination of the corpse, though he did everything required of him.  He missed the real cause of death.  He wouldn't have if he had been more what? Choices:  A: careful B: thoughtful C: complete D: thorough E: intricate<n>Rationales: 1. The question indicates that John did everything required of him but it was in a perfunctory manner, suggesting a lack of detail or thoroughness.<n>2. It is also mentioned that John missed the real cause of death, implying that he was not thorough enough in his examination.<n>3. Among the provided options, "careful", "thoughtful", "complete", "thorough", and "intricate", the latter is the best fit to describe a detailed and comprehensive examination.<n>4. Careful might suggest that he was not being cautious enough, but it doesn't fully capture the inadequacy of the examination. <n>5. Thoughtful implies a level of consideration or contemplation, but doesn't necessarily mean detail oriented.<n>6. Complete might suggest that he did not finish his examination, but the passage states that he did everything that was required of him.<n>7. Intricate implies complexity, but not necessarily comprehensive thoroughness.<n>8. Thus, the option that best fits is "thorough", suggesting that had he been more thorough, he wouldn't have missed the real cause of death.<n>9. Therefore, the answer to the question is D: Thorough.<n>Answer: D: thorough<n><n>### Input:What eastern state is home to a mountain? A, B, C, and E do not fit the required parameters.<n><n><n>### Input <n>What does the French word "saucisson" refer to? Choices:  * A: the cure of meat * B: a cut of meat * C: a style of cooking * D: a style of eating * E: the meat of an animal<n>### Response<n>I am confident that it is D, a style of eating.<n>### Response rationals:<n>The French word "saucisson" in the English context can refer to the meat of an animal, and this is indicated using the word "of" in the context. As such, we can eliminate answers B and A.<n>Choice C is also eliminated as the word "eating" does not describe any cooking style in the French context.<n>The remaining options could refer to culinary styles, such as D and E. However, E does not refer to eating but cooking.<n>As such, choice D makes the most sense since it mentions cooking meat to be eaten as a style of eating, as is described in the question.<n>### I:What word is an anagram of the word "wet" and has the same number of consonants and vowels as "pint"? Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n><n>### Response:		A "river" is "a long, narrow piece of water that flows through a valley with steep banks" (The Free Dictionary by Farlex).<n><n>### It does not seem to be an option because 1. "river" does not refer to the surface of the earth: rivers flow in valleys (not on the surface of the earth).<n><n>### 2. It is not a long piece of water, as rivers typically cover large areas, including the surface of the earth.<n><n>### 3. "Surface of the earth" is not an option, as rivers may not run along the surface of the earth (e.g., underwater rivers, etc.)<n><n>### 4. "Beach" is not an option as it indicates a narrow band of land located along a coast or by a lake or river.<n><n>### It also does not mean a long narrow piece of water, as beaches typically have a smaller surface area.<n><n>### "Underwater" is not an option either, as it does not refer to a river that flows through a valley, as rivers flow in valleys.<n><n>### Intricate might suggest that river is not comprehensively sufficient to answer the question. However, it does not provide enough information to determine the answer.<n><n>### B: underwater:<n>"Underwater: not on the surface of the water." (Oxford Languages).<n><n>### Rivers flow below or under water levels. They flow below the surface of the earth in a valley on the way to the sea, which is where it flows at its widest extent.<n><n>### Examination:Under the direction of his son-in-law, Samuel Leigh Clegg, Henry H. Rogers found a deposit of oil on Santa Paula, California, in 1901.  He became an influential oilman in California.  While working for Mammoth Oil Company in 1920, Rogers used a new method of drilling oil which allowed for faster and less costly drilling and was the predecessor of the modern "nodding donkey" drilling rig.  He built a road bridge over the Rogue River (later burned down by a forest fire). Rogers Street in Grants Pass, and Rogers Mountain in Josephine County, Oregon, were named for him.

Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n><n>### Response:		Concert<n><n>### Input<n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question asks where one would buy a ticket to sit “in a room with a lot” of chairs facing the “same direction”.<n>2. The options provided are “conference”, “theater”, “building”, “floor”, and “church” but none of them sufficiently capture the characteristics of the room described by the question.<n>3. A “conference” room only has a limited number of chairs facing the room, and often tables for presentations or handouts.<n>4. A “theater” room is more suited to shows performed for a large audience.<n>5. Similarly, a “building” or “floor” or “church” room is not suited to having a large number of people sit facing the same direction.<n>6. Thus, the best answer is the only one that captures the characteristic of the room asked about in the question and is “concert".<n><n>### Rationale<n>1. The question is about buying a ticket to sit in the “same direction” in a room with “a lot” of chairs.<n>2. The first option, “conference”, has a limited number of seats and “a lot” of people are not looking toward the front of the room.<n>3. The second option, “theater”, is not appropriate because it is used for presentations.<n>4. The third option, “building”, is also not appropriate because it has walls, floors and ceilings that would not be suited for chairs.<n>5. Similarly with “floor” and “church” which would not be suitable for having a large number of seats arranged in the same direction.<n><n>### Rationales<n>1. Answer each as completely as you can. You must include the question and answer. Make sure your answer makes sense. You must use paragraphs. Your paragraphs must have a topic sentence and supporting details/evidence. Make sure you capitalize each word that is needed.<n>### Input: <n>In the dark, the woman was very frightened before she saw a man. After she saw him, she was much less afraid. Why?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The woman, who found herself quite frightened in the dark but much less afraid after seeing a man, was very afraid because she was alone in the woods and afraid of any possible dangers lurking in the dark.<n><n>### Rationale: <n>Paragraphs are required and must be written in complete sentences containing a topic sentence and supported detail as well as evidence.<n>### Instruc:After walking an hour, the man grew tired. He sat down on the ground, panting. What caused him to be tired while he walked? Choices: A: he lost energy B: he was hungry C: he didn’t eat for a long time D: he was ill E: he became thirsty<n><n>### Response,Rationale<n><n>I believe he was tired because he lost energy. I believe this because the author says "After walking an hour, man grew tired". If he was tired because he was hungry, there would have been the sentence written "After eating an hour, man grew hungry". If he became ill, there would have been some sentence that stated that he got sick.<n>### Instruction,Rationale : <n><n>### Input :It got cold in the morning, and the man realized he was almost out of matches.
